content.paragraph: The new TLH theme requires many new functionalities to display specific features as well as integrate new design flow elements. This part of the document will specify and define each new functionality, identify the snippet blocks and explain the scripted functions associated with them.
Hello Banner

The new hello banner allows for messages to be displayed between specific dates by adding metafield values. The hello banner content is organized into a linklist whose content is fed from basic shopify pages. It can contain short text and links. The linklist is called HelloBar and can be found in the navigation sub menu of shopify admin. To add a new item, create a new page with your custom content and then add that page to the linklist. The Hello Banner is a multilingual element so to separate the English and French text, use the bar-slash-bar separator string. Example :

Get your fill of sale items while they last. <a href="collections/all" title="All collections">Click here</a>.|-|Faites le plein d'articles en solde avant qu'ils ne disparaisent. <a href="collections/all" title="All collections">Cliquez ici</a>
Liquid and javascript don't handle apostrophes in the same manner. In order to avoid errors, add a forward slash ( \ ) before any apostrophe.
Navigation Menu

The navigation menu is perhaps the most sensitive new functionality as it does not use the native shopify index features (a part from the brands tab) to create a hierarchical menu. Instead, the navigation menu reads data from an external .json file that contains a category, child and grandchild hierarchy. This .json file is also used to build and filter the left nav filter feature. The nav.json file is loaded via an ajax call and the menu is built by looping through parent, child and grandchild data. Example of a .json node:

{
"navitems": [
{
"name_en": "Men's",
"name_fr": "Hommes",
"href": "mens",
"level1": [
{
"name_en": "Jackets and vests",
"name_fr": "Manteaux & Vestes",
"href": "jackets",
"visible": true,
"level2": [
{
"name_en": "Insulated",
"name_fr": "Isolés",
"href": "insulated",
"visible": true }
}]
}]
}

In the example above, the script that populates the navigation bar reads and loops through each level. The code snippet above (for simplicity reasons) only has one parent array, one child array and one granchild array. The code will output a hierarchical menu with the parent, MEN'S, a child, JACKETS AND VESTS and a grandchild INSULATED. The parent item's link will be mens. The child item will take the parents link and append it's own href value (and seperator) to create a child link: mens/jackets. The grandchild element takes the child link and appends it's own href value (and seperator) to create a child link: mens/jackets+insulated.
The script loops through all the values in the nav.json file to build a complete hierarchical menu with functional, tag based links.
Language Switcher
See the language parameters section of this document for an overview of this functionality.
Sale Labels
Each product now has a sale, sold out or special sale label displayed over it's picture. Depending on the product status and it's stock, the correct label will display.
Filtered Left Menu

The filtered menu is the most complex new feature. Eight custom functions and 452 lines of code are required to create a functional filter menu. The filter menu displays on all collection and search result pages and allows users to filter within an existing parent or child category and add query parameters (such as brands) to refine the results. A general overview of the function's structure is below.

content.paragraph: The code and page structure are located in sidebar_filtered.liquid. This file also reads the current language to extract the proper data from the nav.json file and reset certain language parameters. Apart from the buildFilter function, all other functions (unless called from within buildFilter) fire on page load in order to avoid conflicts with other scripts and display features. Because of the complexity of the filter menu functions, error collectors and try...catch instructions are used throughout.
Compartmentalized Pre Footer

The pre-footer (need help, keep in touch, social) bar has been re-scripted to enable a snippet based display. This allows some features to be turned off or blocks to be re-ordered. This also enables the mobile site to display each element as a separate component.
Hero Banners

The hero banners are the full screen image(s) found on the index page that contains sale event information. The masthead itself, similar to the hello bar, extracts it's information from a linklist whose content is fed from basic shopify pages. The masthead displays information for both the desktop and mobile versions of the site.

The linklist that contains the hero banners is called HeroBanners and can be found in the Navigation sub menu of shopify admin. The hero banner pages are basic page templates with a specific code (see below) and some meta fields that contain the module data.
Hero banners are multilingual so languages have to be separated with the bar-slash-bar ( |-| ) string.

content.paragraph: Easy Shot

The easy shot component is a hybrid external app - internal custom code component. It uses a bold app function to set sales server-side and an internal custom code to loop through sale products, display product specific information and powers the countdown timer. The countdown timer itself is a separate code feature, scripted as a jquery plugin to enable it's use multiple times on the same page without causing a conflict between elements.
The countdown date format can be changed in the function call's parameters. All time elements can be configured to display a specific date-time format and/or show different separators.
Upcoming Events

The upcoming events feature is identical to the hero banners feature. It's content and functionality is the same. The only difference is that the upcoming events boxes extracts it's data from the page html rather than the metafields. The upcoming event's timer counts up to the sale date.

Reusable Scripted Functions

In order to streamline function execution and extend features site-wide, a library of functions has been created allowing for the execution of redundant or core tasks as well as the implementation of new standards. All of these functions are vanilla javascript and are either executed in page or executed via a jquery event handler. All of these function can be executed in the console for testing purposes.
Below is a list of functions, the task they achieve, the parameters they require and the data they return.
